awd_titl_txt: Learning From Diverse Sources and Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds research in economic theory. Markets are increasingly saturated with very detailed and precise information, such as data about consumer preferences, social networks or product attributes. An important but understudied aspect of these settings is how the multiplicity of sources of information available to consumers and firms affects their decisions, as well as the diverse ways in which this information is interpreted. For example, different past experiences and views of the world may lead individuals to interpret information in starkly different ways. A central objective of the proposed work is to identify the inefficiencies of information production and aggregation that emerge when the informational environment is complex, and to understand the ways in which these inefficiencies can be ameliorated via appropriate restructuring and regulation of the informational environment. There are many possible interventions. For example, a policymaker can release information by making a public announcement or seeding information with specific individuals, restructure the environment by restricting certain kinds of data sharing, or influence how individuals interpret information by providing information about others' preferences or beliefs. The projects funded by this award develop theoretical frameworks for clarifying the differences between these interventions and identifying which are most effective. These findings will be of practical use to inform policy regarding the design, dissemination, and regulation of information. Further, the problem of how to regulate data markets is of recent interest in many disciplines, including computer science, law, and sociology. The research will contribute to this interdisciplinary literature by focusing on the economic consequences to 'big data' production and usage. 

The research plan proposal consists of three projects. The first project focuses on the production of data when agents have access to many interrelated sources of information. The second proposes a model in which information about consumers is pooled across various markets and examines the consequences of sharing this information with firms. The third project considers how agents learn from their peers when they have mis-specified models of inference and seeks to characterize how an information planner can release information or modify the informational environment to facilitate learning. Although there is a classic and well-developed economics literature on learning and information acquisition, consideration of heterogeneity in sources and information-processing models has only recently begun to attract interest. For example, the learning literature has mostly focused on agents with correctly-specified models (i.e. Bayesian learners with priors that put positive weight on the true model). While more recent work has focused on the case where agents have mis-specified models, the question of what happens when agents with different mis-specified models interact is an important open channel for research. Similarly, the information acquisition literature has mostly studied learning from a single source, focusing on questions such as how much information should an agent acquire, and at what level of precision. Recent work introduces diverse information sources and studies dynamic information acquisition patterns. But study of the economic interactions between agents who aggregate information across diverse sources, e.g. in market settings, where firms aggregate information across consumers and markets for screening, remains incomplete.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Markets are increasingly saturated with very detailed information, such as data about consumer preferences, friendship networks, or product attributes. Key aspects of these settings include the multiplicity of sources available to decision-makers and the diverse ways in which individuals interpret these sources. For example, a consumer choosing between medical treatments may observe the choices or outcomes of peers, the recommendations of a health agency, and the opinions of multiple doctors.  Similarly, firms use retail and social media data, aggregated across sites, to target consumers. In these complex settings, agents must decide what information to acquire and how to aggregate the different sources. Moreover, different views of the world and past experiences may lead agents to process this information in starkly different ways.

 

This project studied how individuals acquire information and learn when the informational environment is complex in the ways described above. The resulting body of research can be broadly grouped into two key areas. The first studied how agents with limited attention or resources learn from different sources of information. The second explored how agents learn when they have informational biases—captured by a misspecified or wrong model of the world. The foundational papers modeled how agents choose between multiple sources of information and how agents learn from their peers when they have heterogeneous models of inference. These papers showed that such settings are vulnerable to inefficiencies. When there is an ``overabundance" of informational sources, agents may become stuck in learning traps: they continue choosing less informative sources, despite the existence of sources that would lead to faster learning. Relatedly, when agents differ in their strategic sophistication or their beliefs about the informational content of different sources, they may fail to efficiently aggregate information from their peers. This can lead to mislearning (beliefs converge to the incorrect state) or cyclical learning (beliefs do not non-convergence), as well as perpetual disagreement. 

 

Subsequent work built on these foundational papers. This included papers that study how abundant data affects incentives, the trade-off between fairness and accuracy in algorithmic design, humans versus machines as decision-makers, how informational biases impact optimal lending contracts, the connection between the misspecified model approach and empirical work on biased belief formation, and how the complexity of the informational environment impacts the resulting informational biases that emerge. An Annual Review article aggregated the research on misspecified models from this project and other researchers into an accessible and comprehensive review piece. Taken together, this project led to 11 papers, including seven of which are published or accepted at journals.

 

The results from this project have several broader impacts. One of the PIs (Aislinn Bohren) has applied the model misspecification research from this project to the topic of discrimination, examining how biased beliefs can lead to differential treatment. This research overlaps with psychology, law, and public policy. This application also has an impact outside of academia, as it informs the public’s understanding of how discrimination impacts economic markets. This project’s work on algorithmic fairness and big data are relevant topics in computer science. This work also informs policy related to data privacy, regulation of data markets, and the use of algorithms to improve decision-making. Both PIs presented this work widely at interdisciplinary workshops related to these applications.

 

This project provided crucial research training to several economics Ph.D. students. It funded a graduate research assistant for the majority of its duration and provided summer funding to several graduate students. In addition to the financial support, these positions provided valuable training opportunities, enabling the students to learn about the research process. Two of the research assistants went on to coauthor with Bohren. Liang also developed important coauthor relationships with graduate students for papers in this project. These are important stepping stones for students as they learn to develop an independent research agenda. This project also provided travel support for the PIs to attend conferences and seminars, which were attended by graduate students and often accompanied by meetings with them. 

 

The work developed in this project enhanced educational opportunities at the graduate and undergraduate level. Both PIs taught their work in Ph.D. elective courses that include economics, business and computer science students. Liang developed a new undergraduate economics course at the intersection with computer science that touches on topics from this project such as privacy and algorithmic fairness. Finally, the Annual Review article provides a useful reference for faculty interested in teaching this topic and students interested in learning this topic independently.
